Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class taught me incredibly important and enlightening information on the mind and how we think.  The material we covered was unlike any other class I have taken before.  Even though not all the material was necessarily interesting to me, I certainly feel like I have walked away with a new perspectives and knowledge I can apply to the world.
Great foundation of the course material.

I came into Yale considering a Cognitive Science major, and wanted to take the class to get a survey of the field. This class really introduced me to a variety of topics, and I am very glad I took the course. I hope to take more cognitive science courses in the future.
how the mind works!!!! A survey on cognitive science.
How our mind works

The course presented a huge amount of information, all of which was interesting to learn and think about, but how relevant it will be to further learning, I'm not sure. The class was one taken for pure interest more than anything else.
I learned a lot of interesting facts and approaches to cognitive science, and the variety of opportunities there are for research in cognitive science.
Through taking this class, I was made aware of things that happen around me everyday and why they happen.
I learned so much (on an intro level, of course) about how the human mind works.

I got a short introduction to many of the fields that make up Cognitive Science. It was challenging only being exposed to very basic material, especially considering that other intro courses like Intro Psych are already very small windows into the fields. I learned how to read lab reports and feel like I have a fairly good, broad understanding of CogSci.
I learned about a field that I had no idea existed.

A comprehensive idea of how humans perceive the world around them and why, as well as an extensive introduction to the different areas of cognitive science and why they are each important to understanding who we are.
This course is not substantive for anyone who has taken relevant courses.
An introduction to interesting cognitive science principles that are influential in other fields like psychology, economics, etc.

Cognitive science is a super broad field. This course skims the surface of a wide variety of topics, but all more or less deal with how our brains perceive and process the world. A lot of the stuff may seem boring or irrelevant, but some of the material may change how you think about perception. The disconnect between the outside world and our mental representations of it is particularly important to become aware of.

I learned a great deal about the human brain and how it works, including linguistics, language acquisition, innateness, modularity, visual perception, decision-making, and many other various topics within these categories.

The course covered a lot of material in a short amount of time, but that's okay because it was an introductory course to one of the broadest and interdisciplinary fields of study offered at Yale. I learned a lot about subjects I didn't even know I was interested in, and am now considering majors like cognitive science and computer science that weren't on my radar before this semester.

This course taught me hoot take good notes. The lectures are entertaining and enjoyable, but the notes are not extremely straightforward. The class keeps you on your toes. 
Coming into CogSci blind having no knowledge of the material, I feel like I've learned a lot, from perception, to modularity, to how animals teaches about our own cognition, and so on. Lectures were informative, challenging, and fun.

Cognitive science is an interdisciplinary field that, together using its six or so subjects, tries to solve how the mind works. In one semester, you basically learn some introductory linguistics, introductory philosophy, introductory behavioral economics, introductory psychology, and introductory neuroscience. Every day, my mind was fascinated about itself; the mind is a beautifully complicated thing that you get to learn more about in this class!
I learned a lot about how the brain works and how it influences our day to day behavior. Final paper really helped me to think for myself as opposed to a research paper.

I gained a much better understanding of cognitive science as a field, and a lot of knowledge in many of cogsci's subfields. The course was super fascinating and helped to display the realm of possibility within the discipline.

I learned so much from this course! Great way to get a solid foundation in Cognitive Science. The topics we went over included Language, Attraction, Vision, Decision-Making, and Computation (to name a few).
I learned about many topics in cognitive science and gained the skill of thinking about the role of mind in simple daily events.
A large spread of information about cognitive science, ranging from phenomena such as instinct blindness to the science behind how fMRI works.
This class made me decide that I will likely be a Cognitive Science major. I learned a great deal about the mind and the way that it works.

Brian Scholl is all over the place and spends too much time trying to relate to the students. He makes jokes that waste my time. He wastes the first 10 minutes of class setting up and then complains at the end of class that we don't have enough time and keeps us late when I have a section to go to on science hill. Additionally, a lot of what we covered was very surface level and many things not described well. Brian Scholl should take his class more seriously.
I learned how to do assignments quickly and how to skim. I also learned about everyday phenomena we take for granted.
Many new skills. New insights into my possible major. New perspectives on the human brain.

this course's main takeaway was that of instinct blindness: we think we know things but we really don't understand their nuances--it opened up a world of study about the mind that I didn't realize existed
I gained general knowledge of the themes common to cognitive science research and about some particular areas of cognitive science.

This class covered so many fascinating topics, not in too much detail but in enough detail to accentuate how interesting each topic is. We started off with foundational knowledge like mind modularity, the evolution of the mind, instinct blindness, and cognitive architecture, then moved on to broader "applications" of cognitive science in the real world from infant cognition to linguistics to the cognitive science of love, sex, and attraction. The weekly articles we had to read and respond to also taught me how to be a more diligent consumer of scientific text. Overall, I learned quite a bit!
I learned a lot about how the mind works when performing common, everyday tasks. The reasoning and decision-making unit was especially applicable to daily life in the real world.
Many interesting insights into studies regarding the human mind as well as developing a vocabulary to discuss and consider many ideas that come intuitively.

Before taking this course, I thought that there was no such thing as human nature, that people were merely products of their societies. Cognitive Science proved me wrong. It showed me how we are a combination of nature and nurture. By showing the ways in which human minds are systematically good or bad at, it helped me look at people more empathetically. It helped me look at issues of morality in a different way I never thought was possible.
I learnt everything I now know on Cognitive Science, even the fact that it existed as a discipline.

I learned about a lot of answers to questions I didnt know I didnt know. That was perhaps the biggest takeaway for me- carving the mind at its joints, many of which were previously unknownst at to me. In a way, this gave voice to a lot of curiosities I already had, but was never able to explore in a structured and productive manner.
A really great survey course of a lot of different topics. Taking it as a first year was great because I now I know a lot more classes I want to explore.

Before this course, I knew very little about the field of cognitive science. Brian Scholl's lectures provided an excellent introduction to different themes, domains, and tools in cognitive science. I just applied to the major!
I found a greater appreciation for why it matters to study the mind and how it perceives the world. I also discovered new reasons why I perceive the world in the way I do.

I gained a solid understanding of a very wide breadth of topics. More than anything, I gained a new perspective, as the course focused on the mind as a computer -- optimized by evolutionary history and performing with flawed efficiency. I gained an understanding of most every facet of this conceptualization.
I learned a lot about how the brain works, not just psychology terms.
learned what cog sci is and how it is applicable in the world. learned a lot about many different subjects
I learned a lot about cognitive science, and I learned that I am very interested in the subject.
I learned about how certain aspects of the mind work. It truly broadened my understanding of how intricate our minds are
Introductory level understanding of basic cognitive science principles in fields such as computation, linguistics, and decision-making.

I learned about a new field of research that I had never heard about before. I learned how many subjects such as AI, neuroscience, psychology and more can be combined to facilitate the extremely complex study of the human mind and its processes.

-learned about what the mind is and how it works
-learned how to read cogsci research papers and extract the hypothesis, procedures, and conclusions
-learned how to explain everyday phenomena through a scientific lens (e.g. inattentional blindness, confirmation bias)
I gained a familiarity with and better understanding of the field of cognitive science.
Scientific thinking skills and the ability to marvel at the commonplace!
A background survey on the basic cognitive science concepts, on how human mind operates

We learned a broad overview of some of the biggest themes and subfields in Cognitive Science. Pretty much every unit was interesting and applicable to my own life. I recommend just reading the syllabus to get a better idea of the exact topics covered, but overall they were all fascinating and cool things to learn about.
this course is a wonderful survey of the basics of the functions of the human mind

I learned about the various aspects of cognitive science, including linguistics, language acquisition, cognitive architecture, perception, philosophy, neuroscience, and more. This course is definitely a good introduction to the field, and interesting even to those who may not pursue cognitive science further.
I learned how to question my own instincts--about everything!

This was one of the courses I have learned the most at during my time at Yale. Highly recommended, especially over your standard Intro Psych class. It touches on many different specialties of cognitive science, and for someone looking to narrow-in on a specific one, it goes in-depth in each one enough to do so.
Intro to all areas of cognitive science: linguistics, computer science, psychology, statistics, etc.

An understanding of what cognitive science really is -- aka how it differs from neuroscience, etc --  and an introduction to its varying subfields such as linguistics, perception, and psychology. The final paper developed my ability to generate my own ideas about the material instead of regurgitating others' scientific studies.

Time management
 Versatility in problem-solving
 Information about a variety of interconnected topics
I learned what the field of cognitive science even is and how it is impacting our lives today. I previously had no idea what cognitive science was and how it interacted with lots of other fields.
I learned the basics of Cognitive Science.
Gave me a solid conceptual understanding of the foundations of cognitive science, gave me a strong interest in the area and all of the disciplines it covers

I was able to explore the concept of "Cognitive Science" as a whole, learning about such an interesting phenomenon while hearing lectures from such an esteemed professor. I also learned how to read through many professional and academic papers.
Kinda like AP psych, but somehow less intense lol

You learn a lot of scientific and psychological concepts in relation to cognitive science. This course is full of scientific readings and lectures that go over different experiments and cognitive science questions. I learned a lot about illusions, that vision is a lie, and other fun, quirky, but enlightening bits of knowledge in cognitive science.
An introductory understanding of the Cognitive Sciences.

I learned so much about so many different aspects of the mind. I also got a very good sense for what cognitive science is, something that I really did not know going into this course. I learned how to think about the mind holistically and how to look at papers and studies critically with an eye for bias.

I was albe to learn about what it meant to be inherently human and what the human mind does that makes it so unique and difficult to understand. I was able to do this by learning about linguistics, philosophy, perception, neuroscience, computer science, and many other areas of thought. These allowed me to think critically and to examine different ways of thinking and the reasons behind the way that our mind works.
We learned a random collection of topics in cognitive science.
A broad overview on what cognitive science is, learned specific experiments to prove principles

I learned about differing aspects of cognitive science-- linguistics, visual perception, modularity, instinct blindness, and many more. Some of these are extremely applicable in the real world, and to concepts other than cognitive science itself, so we discussed that as well.
I learned how the human mind functioned

I learned a huge amount about cognitive science. It was fascinating to learn about how human beings operate from a mental standpoint. I appreciated leaning about perception, and behavior, and fMRI especially.
I actually learned truly invaluable lessons in this class it was fascinating and really enjoyable. I now know so many cool things.

This course offered general exposure to an interdisciplinary web of cognitive science subjects like linguistics, computer science, and experimental psychology. Mostly consisted of random, disjointed case studies connected through themes like innateness and modularity.
Different disciplines that contribute to the study of the mind!
I learned a very basic understanding of cognitive science.
I learnt about the different disciplines involved with congitive science.

I have learned to think more critically about the underlying concepts that drive human cognition. I now have a greater knowledge of the world around me, seen through the meshing of multiple disciplines.

Knowledge: Key cogsci concepts like modularity, encapsulation, instinct blindness; domains like infant cognition, neuroscience, comparative cognition, computer science, language, vision, reasoning, philosophy.
Skills: Reading scientific papers, formal representations such as turing machines and context free grammars / syntax trees, thinking about why it matters (you write a paper on this).
Insights: Trustworthy science / scientific fallacy; the idea of explanation and what is good science; deep questions such as "How does matter give rise to consciousness?"; deep answers such as the magic is in the patterns, not the parts. The idea of the uniqueness of human thought vs. other species vs. computers; illusions + when / whether our eyes are lying to us / being influenced by our thoughts, desires, etc.; illusions and heuristics of reasoning + how to defend against fallacy. More than anything, starting in a lifestyle after fresh understanding of the quote, "a common man marvels at the extraordinary; a wise man marvels at the commonplace," - our visual, language, reasoning, etc. systems work in highly unintuitive, fascinating ways that can be uncovered by sound science.
I learned about Cognitive Science and the various disciplines, including linguistics, artificial intelligence, neuroscience, and many other topics.
I developed a deeper understanding of a wide range of topics and fields of study, as well as their relationship with the human brain.

This class was a complete introduction to cognitive science for me. I had never taken a course in this area before and I found it both manageable and very interesting. I definitely developed a greater insight into the human brain and cognitive functions.
This class teaches you a little about a lot, such as linguistics, perception, modularity in the brain, human behavior, etc.
I learnt about the different domains of cognitive science.

I lean red about the mind, what it is and how it works. I also learned how much we still don't know but the various methods that we use to find more information. I also learned about the true interdisciplinary nature of the course and how with the different sciences working together, insight can be found.

Although the lecture material was interesting, the organization of material in lectures was kind of all over the place.  While studying, I found I spent a lot of time trying to understand why certain topics were presented and why they fit into the bigger picture of everything.
The lectures are remarkably engaging. Some of the most excited students Ive experienced in a yale classroom.

The course is organized well and in a fashion where nothing was boring. The only weakness is that the number of readings is too excessive to be able to read everything, but the tests make up for this with skips (which I used on reading-related questions).

This course was very disjointed and thinly spread. It is a "mile wide, inch deep course" by design, which I understand as a weakness. Lectures were fascinating and every day introduced new material, but internalizing that material was difficult because of its superficial nature. Furthermore readings were long, dense, and sometimes incomprehensible. Combined with the fact that there is no textbook for the course, this complicated the studying process, as all information -- regardless of how complicated, or whether or not it was from the reading or lecture -- was fair game. 

There was a very steep disconnect between Professor Scholl and the TFs of the class. Before the first exam, I asked a question to my TF and was given a completely wrong answer that lost me points on multiple questions and thus harmed my grade. Often I felt like the TFs did not know the course material, and were far more confused than the students. 

Most of our readings came from Professor Scholl's research. It is impossible to gain an objective understanding of an emerging field when only looking at one man's understanding, and Professor Scholl did little to increase our knowledge of other researchers and ideas besides his.

Strengths: Very interesting material, lecture slides well organized and easy to read, reasonable tests and assignments

Weaknesses: At some points, it was difficult to see connecting factors between lectures because we covered so many subjects.
Professor Scholl ends up running behind schedule very early on, so the latter half of the course is quite disorganized with how he shifts topics/readings around.
The biggest strength of this course is that there are no weaknesses.

Amazing professor.
Fun readings.
Easy exams.

The content of the course was very interesting, but hard to test as the information is just presented (expected as most comes from complex studies). However, this leads to exams which comprise primarily of regurgitating information.

There was a lot of interesting information throughout the course, and some of it is rather helpful to know if you're thinking of pursuing cognitive science. However, some of the exam questions and the essay topic were rather vague, and it was hard to really understand what was being asked and what is useful to know. The lectures were often falling behind as well since Scholl often went on tangents.

Some strengths are that the topics are interesting and pretty engaging. Some weaknesses are that with a class that big, it is difficult to get useful feedback and the tests do not seem to reflect the level of difficulty of the class during the semester.

While most of the course was excellent, we spent an inordinate amount of time on computation, perception, and linguistics. Those are important, but it would have been nice to have time for morality (which got pushed off the syllabus when we fell behind).

Overall a good course. Sometimes the content seemed disconnected and Scholl often didn't get through the content/went overtime to rush things. We never received feedback on our reading response, though, which would have been helpful.

I really liked how we read a variety of primary sources as opposed to a single, standard textbook. The material was very interesting; I just wish I got more of each topic. I acknowledge, however, that this is a difficult ask given the time limitations.
The lecturing is wonderful and easy to understand, however it is challenging to study for tests since it relies purely on your own lecture notes.

I liked the survey style of this course because each class was completely different, new, and exciting. Each lecture was engaging and exposed me to ideas that I never before considered. At the end of the class I was left wanting to learn more about cognitive science, and I am looking forward to taking another cogsci course in the future.
stop trying to be a survey course and a weeder course at the same time.

It is super interesting and has super little work.

I think the course is fine, there are plenty of demonstrations to keep you interested, and the topic as a whole is interesting.

It's a big course, and you may find your level of engagement steadily sinking throughout its duration, but all in all it's a well designed, very manageable course. There are only two exams and one paper, so the academic demand is pretty low.
It gives you a good overview of the field of cognitive science, but it is very empirical and experiment-based which makes it sort of confusing and not that convincing.
The YUAG auditorium's lighting is horrible. Each test we took was basically done in the dark.

A strength of this class is its lectures; the material is well-covered and easy to follow, as well as interesting because Scholl uses multi-media presentations to teach and keep your engagement. The other strength is its guest lectures, by Scaz, Josh Knobe, and HoC Santos; after each of these guest lectures, I felt a powerful inspiration to continue with cognitive science, because these guest lecturers show you beautiful things that this field can do (like how robots + cognitive science can be used to teach deaf children to speak ASL, for example). 

A weakness of this class is the correlation between material and homework, and then the midterm and final. For the first midterm, I felt well-prepared having studied all the lectures and done all of the readings. However, the questions on the exam can be tricky because they require  applications of the information you learn in class. Thus, I think it'd be cool to have some sort of practice questions or some sort of activity that allows you to practice application questions before the midterm.

This course covers a lot of interesting material. However, a lot of time wasted in the class. 10-20 minutes at the beginning of each class is used for logistics that could be addressed in an email. The tests are also graded so formulaically that they often test your ability to memorize Scholl's wording of a concept more than one's actual understanding of the concept.

Strengths:
- very lively class
- very interesting for anyone (even someone not wanting to pursue a CogSci major)

Weaknesses: 
- reading questions were not very helpful in any way although the readings were

The course was really fantastic and Prof Scholl did a great job of making each lecture interesting and engaging. The slides Prof Scholl posted weren't comprehensive at all, so it's really important to go to the lectures.
I hope the some of the course content would be better organized and more clearly presented

Very interesting material. I appreciate that the exams gave you the option to skip several questions. My TA was not helpful at all though, so thank God I was taking this Credit-D or my GPA would have plummeted. Also, the reading responses we had twice a week were quite excessive and painful.

The strengths include providing insight to what cognitive science is and how we explore mind in different ways. This course also taught the students about how daily processes occur in a way that we never thought of. I believe that this course can be improved by having more engaged TAs who hold more review sessions and give more feedback to students along the way for the course since it is a large lecture course. Also, it would be helpful if the instructor provided sample exams or optional quizzes so that the students can ensure they have taken enough notes and understood the materials for each lecture. Providing videos of the lectures would be very helpful as well.

Very engaging material covered in lecture, didn't like how it was ambiguous how much of the readings you had to understand for lectures and the tests. I liked the format of the class. I didn't like how the lecture slides weren't posted properly on the website. I think the teacher has a very strong grasp of his subject.
A greater connection between the topics first semester could be affirmed. Also if class started and ended on time.

Regularly interesting lecture material, thoroughly new topic for me. Exciting material overall. I wish sometimes we spent less in class time going over the readings, and more in class time discussing the readings assuming that people had read them. If a student did not read them that is their loss.

the linguistics lecture was the most boring lecture i have ever sat through at yale. but guest lectures were fantastic, learning about love, sex, and attraction, robots, etc. was generally engaging but it was at times difficult to know what was just scholl rambling and what was material we would be tested on. i learned a lot, partly due to the fact that my notes were taken by hand and i didn't have internet access

I liked this course's content and general layout (2 midterms and the paper, with no final). I think the only thing that felt weak about the course was that the paper felt so separate from what we did in class. I understand that this was by design, but if the prompt could have let us draw more from things we discussed in class I think it would have added more to our understanding.

I honestly loved this class and the structure. Because each lecture was essentially an introduction to a new topic, I was never bored with the material, and Professor Scholl did an amazing job making a huge lecture interactive with fun little optic illusions and videos of experiments interspersed between lectures. Review sessions were well conducted for tests, and all information was made easily accessible. The only thing I would say is that the slides posted online were very incomplete, so for people like me who take notes by hand without the slides, it was sometimes hard to go back and study exactly what Scholl had taught us.

I think one strength is that the professor is very engaging and the information is interesting enough to keep the lecture captivating for the entire hour and a half. I think it could be improved by having more useful/helpful review sessions before the tests.

The lectures are all spectacular. I think the best way to improve it would be to have fewer readings but greater writing requirements for the readings we do do, forcing us to be more engaged with them.

Introduction to Cognitive Science is a "survey course" since Cognitive Science itself is a very interdisciplinary field. This is both a strength and a weakness of the course. 

It is a strength since it lets students explore many fields and create a path for their future studies. It is a weakness because you never have enough time to go deeper into areas and topics. From time to time, this caused frustration for me since even though I knew everything Brian told us in the lecture, I didn't feel like I *knew* the topic. I needed to go into more detail to be able to say that in confidence.

The strengths definitely lie in the fascination the topics discussed generate.

A weakness would be the difficulty of some of the papers we are required to read.

Strengths
-wide range of topics that seem carefully chosen and are all relatively interesting
-very interesting readings that were for the most part relevant to the lectures, actually augmentint our undwrstaneing of the topics
-very engaging and entertaining lectures
-Paola was super nice as my TF 
-final paper was an interesting assignment 

Weaknesses
-sort of eclectic mix of topics that made it difficult to study any in serious depth
-lack of a textbook to flesh topics out by oneself
-some TFs really werent helpful/didnt seem to know what they were talking about
Brian Scholl is a fabulous lecturer and I was excited to come to class almost every day.

This course often felt a little ~fluffy~. We would spend a whole lecture on a topic, like perception for example, and I would leave lecture hall without feeling that I had gained any tangible, new knowledge beyond a few cool illusions. Then, come midterms/finals, I found a huge disparity between the rigor of lecture and the rigor of the written exam. The exam questions were far more challenging than lecture, but they did show me I had learned something! The assigned readings were also difficult, so I think lecture could be balanced to more closely resemble the readings and level of detail/information expected upon the examinations. That might prepare students better!
The professor was very engaging and the lectures were honestly a joy to go to.
I thought he was a very smart professor, extremely engaging but some of the things were not thoroughly explained and you fell behind if you did not understand it at first.

reading responses pretty much forced me to do the readings which was nice because it made me accountable.

tests were a lot. review sessions sucked because one TA paula didn't know what she was doing the entire time which was embarrassing when asked a question she would just pass it on or answer something confusing which just discouraged the class. sammy was great though he answered everyone's questions and knew what he was doing. very smart

lectures were great and not hard to sit through. fun even

Strengths: Interesting course material

Weaknesses: Only 3 assignments make up the total grade
Strengths is that it is very interesting and engaging.
Incredibly engaging lectures, insightful readings, and overall a great course.
Class has great and engaging material. It is a large lecture so it may have been beneficial to split the class up into sections to review material.

Strengths: 
-the variety of topics covered
-the chance to catch a glimpse of current and past research
-everything we learn in the course can be traced back to a few key themes or principles
Weaknesses:
-can only get brief exposure to topics 
-little feedback given on personal performance

To improve: 
-place less weight on the tests, because they account for 60% of the grade and just a few points off could significantly affect your grade

The things we covered in the latter half of the term was very interesting and engaging. However, the pace at the beginning of the term was a little bit slow to me and I thought maybe we could have spent less time on the general fields and principles and go into the individual fields and topics a little earlier on.

Strength: Professor Scholl is very engaging, funny and experienced. He made all the lessons delightful to attend
Weakness: The class always starts late and wasted a lot of time at the beginning of the class each time to tackle technical or administrative issues. As a result, we ended up not able to catch up with the syllabus
How to improve: would be better if we can start on time and focus more on the real content of the class material rather than announcements/Q&A on homework assignments etc.

The biggest strength was Professor Scholl's lectures. He was engaging, entertaining, great at explaining complicated subjects, and obviously deeply knowledgeable about each of the many topics he talked about. The tests were well written and a good check for understanding and the readings were relevant and ranged from easy to difficult with appropriately difficult reading questions.
My main complaint is on the paper that was worth 20% of the final grade, as it felt more like an evaluation of creative writing than understanding of the course.
Great variety of information

Strengths- really interesting readings, taken directly from academic journals on the subject and often at the forefront of current research
Weaknesses- lack of interaction outside of lecture with the material

Absolutely love Brian's teaching style. Slides could potentially use more pictures of his cute daughter. The combination of tests and an essay was helpful in letting different strengths show. Exams were completely fair. 

A weakness I did spot was that it felt impossible to guess what your grade was and understand how you were doing in the class until the moment final grades were posted. That caused some stress. Discussion sections would have been hugely helpful.

The only downside of this course is that there are no quizzes and a limited number of homework assignments. That means almost the entire weight of the course is given to the midterm and final, which are each extremely difficult in their own right. If you do not do well on one, it is hard to do well in the class.

This class is incredibly interesting, but can be scattered at times, which makes it hard to study for exams. A bit more organization/clarity could make this course stronger, but overall -- it's definitely a great class that explores exciting material.

It was an interesting course, but it could have been organized a bit better. Often the organization was hard to follow, which made studying for the exams quite difficult. 

Additionally, the review sessions led by the TAs before the exams proved that the class was so poorly organized, even they didn't know what was going on. There must have been little communication with Professor Scholl because when legitimate questions that were asked during review sessions, the TAs often did not know the answer, told us it would not be important, and then those exact questions were asked on the test where we were graded extremely harshly and expected to know specific details that the TAs clearly had not known during any reviews.

Brian's lectures are a huge strength of this course! He is very funny and super engaged with his students -- he sticks around after lectures to chat and gives a lot of book recommendations, which is a another big strength. Exams were fair, if a bit tailored to Brian's exact wording of concepts, but if you take good notes in class this shouldn't be a problem. As for weaknesses, there aren't a lot of opportunities to assess what knowledge you've retained. Lectures felt like fun TED talks, with exams as reluctantly necessary afterthoughts. There aren't any opportunities to practice concepts so you can feel a bit lost while reviewing, especially because topics are covered for breadth instead of depth.

Strengths:
 The course material is extremely interesting
 The course is centered around central themes and topics, which lends structure to the material

Weaknesses:
 Because Cognitive Science contains so many different subjects, it is difficult to organize the material in an ideal way to facilitate student learning. At times the central takeaways of lectures were difficult to understand, because they were scattered amid many examples.
 The lecture slides uploaded to the website were almost always incomplete, especially when it came to examples, which made it difficult to study them.

I thought the lectures were engaging and the exams pretty fair. Some of the readings were quite long, but that was made up for by the fact that our responses didn't need to take very long. 

If anyone every missed a lecture that would be pretty detrimental in the long run, but if you went to every lecture and took notes then I thought this class was structured in a way that it was possible to succeed and learn.
The weakness of this course is that it is extremely difficult to learn the material because the lecture notes are not clear.
It's taught with a lot of introductory information, but the exams are quite difficult. Content is interesting though. As a whole the class is much more difficult than advertised.

Brian Scholl is a great lecturer, the material was super interesting and it wasn't hard to keep up with the readings. This is a very broad intro course with lots of material to cover, so it was bound to feel superficial at times. However, it definitely made me want to take more courses in specific areas so I can go more in depth in the future. I also thought that most of the readings were great, but some of them were so technical that I didn't get much out of themI would've preferred to have more readings that incorporated philosophy/conceptual stuff.
More information could definitely be packed into each lecture. About 15 or so minutes of solid material in each lecture, I felt.

The course is structured fairly well, with the lectures usually posted before class begins. The lectures are clear and understandable. It would be great if the lectures posted online contained all the graphic images and content that is seen in class. It's hard to catch up on a lecture if you miss a class and have to rely on these vague PDFs. The course has 2 midterms, and 1 paper. The grade is made up of those and participation from the reading responses you submit every Monday and Wednesday based on the reading that is assigned. The readings are fairly helpful and responses are straightforward to do. The midterm material is quite random, and based on random things focused on in class. If you're a senior, make sure you don't have interviews or have to be out of town on any day this lecture is offered. Otherwise, you will fail the midterm. Take notes on everything, because you will never really know what will be on the exam. Concepts are key to know, but its hard to know from the lectures the definite answer to some questions. It may be best to take this class credit D.

The lectures for this course were fantastic. Professor Scholl does a great job of keeping students engaged and relating concepts to the real world. I thought this course succeeded in introducing us to a wide variety of disciplines and subjects of study under the umbrella of cogsci. Because of the class size, there isn't much individualized feedback which is one of its only weaknesses.
The material is exceptionally engaging, however, the class is very large.
I cannot think of any weaknesses. This course was incredible. The lectures are incredibly engaging and informative, and the workload is very reasonable and pertinent to class.

it was great having class to explain the concepts that were difficult to understand in the readings however it would be helpful if the readings were more accessible and understandable for people that have not had experience with the material or concepts like that being presented because many of the readings and homework assignments were very abstract and detailed but difficult to comprehend. some were explained in class which was helpful but some questions were sill left unanswered.

While I find the course material very interesting, the way in which we learned it was very random and varied deeply in its depth.  I liked the way it was assessed, though I wish it were much more clear on what we would be evaluated, and I think the readings were very interesting.
The lectures are very interesting

It's a very interesting course; each lecture felt like a TED Talk and Prof. Scholl is a great lecturer. It could use a little more organization so each lecture doesn't feel like a completely separate entity, but that's also just the nature of cognitive science as something very interdisciplinary, and I didn't think the lack of organization was necessarily super harmful to the class.
we could have more discussions related to course readings

I thought that the lectures were wonderful, and the tests were fair. I also very much enjoyed having to read studies and articles. A weakness of this course is not being able to discuss the material in small groups.
The testing in the form of mere multiple choice and short answer didn't fully encapsulate what we know. It felt lazy.

Lectures are relaxing and low-key. Little outside work is required to keep up with the class. The main weakness of the course is discontinuity. Because it essentially offers samples of all different topics and methods (only united under the idea of the human mind), the overall course lacks structure and continuity. You leave feeling that you've learned about a lot of weird and interesting phenomena but you've gained no deep knowledge about any particular thing.
It is a very inspiring class, but it could be slightly more organized.

I think this course was very good for people who have had a little background in computer science. I found the turing machines extremely difficult but I think overall the course was an excellent overview of cognitive science.

I think there is a good amount of misused time (specifically in the beginning of lectures). They started late a lot. Also I feel as if the TA grading system could be improved upon. Also they always seemed to make tests at the last second. Lots of Very interesting material and overall he is extremely good at lecturing
You learn some cool stuff but because cognitive science is so broad, you never really go in depth into anything.
The course was very interesting and I was always happy to attend lecture. Yet, the exams were quite strange.

Strengths: best lecture experience at Yale over my 3 years. Crystal clear explanations; breadth and depth. Interesting readings; reading questions keep you honest = good. Fair, interesting exams.

Weaknesses: Lack of feedback on assignments (you have to individually seek out your TA to see your midterm / paper). Many possible improvements over this system. Other courses have emailed a copy of my paper with comments + grade justification. I got a C on the final paper and have little incentive to dispute / understand why / reach a sense of catharsis. 
If the TA's are spending any more time than the absolute minimum "what is my impression of this paper's deserved grade" after one read-through, it is a waste because their thoughts are lost on most students, myself included. It seems we're stuck between a "rock" of cynical apathy and a "hard place" of wasted effort.
professor's lecture slides are extremely unorganized and they lack the essential information that is required to succeed in exams.

This course captured my imagination in its depiction of cognition. Everyday, right after class, I called my friends and family just to tell them the amazing things I learned. the weakness of the course lies in its unclear expectation of knowledge for the assessments presented.
The lectures were very engaging, but it was difficult to learn about what we needed to know for the test.

Strengths - very interesting material, variety of topics, Brian Scholl's jokes, interactive lectures, guest lectures

Weaknesses - Brian Scholl's jokes, felt like every lecture was a different TEDtalk and although Brian tried to connect them all sometimes it was hard to see the connections
Great class, super interesting, and the professor is incredibly intriguing and comedic during lecture.
The unit on Case Assignment at the end of the year is obnoxious and should be taken out of the syllabus

I think one strength was that the material presented was usually very interesting, enough that students would often be surprised at what they were learning. However, I did find some of the topics, as well as many of the assignment prompts, to be quite vague, making them a lot more difficult to understand.

I thought that the lectures and readings were interesting, and I actually learned something from them. The exams were fair, and there was a decent curve on them. The reading responses were annoying and were just a nuisance, as you rarely learned anything new from them and they didn't make you think too hard.
I liked that we covered significant breadth in the. Course, by felt that the syllabus was slightly too touch and go.
We could have more interaction with the TAs.
I would recommend this course for the material but I wouldn't recommend it for the class structure and facilitation.

I would highly recommend the course, as it opens your eyes to aspects of the world and daily life you would never notice otherwise. Even if you have no interest in psychology, it is a fascinating and exciting class.

No, I would not. The course was disjointed and broad. I took the class because I thought the material was interesting. I still do, but the learning experience was not worth the stress and egregiously long readings. If I could go back in time and stop myself from taking this class, I would. I felt that my time and efforts were not respected, and that I learned a lot of trivia instead of a functional foundation.
Yes; it's a great course to get a survey of cognitive science.

I did not enjoy taking this class. Brian Scholl is an entertaining and humorous lecturer, but his lectures are opinionated and light on concrete material. This course can be best described as a collection of useful tidbits or facts about various topics. Understandably, this is an introduction to cognitive science, but I see the insane breadth as a drawback. We covered everything from principles of cognitive architecture, to Turing machines, to language and phrase markers, to robotics, to animal cognitionafter a while it all started to lack meaning. 

A side-effect of this breadth is that it makes the entire field look a little pseudosciency. In one of our last lectures, Prof. Scholl deplored just-so explanations that explain the obvious. But it seemed that we were routinely utilizing just-so explanations to explain away otherwise interesting problems and phenomena. For instance, visual illusions were accounted for by jargon such as coincidence avoidance and instinct blindness without any strict separation between the two. Similarly, the behavior of ants and bees was attributed to instances of dead-reckoning and chemo-signaling without much elaboration. This continued into the rest of the course, and I would have liked to see on increased focus on computer science and neuroscience.

But the course does have some positives: As previously stated, Prof. Scholl is a rare, charismatic and comedic lecturer, so its hard to fall asleep. The reading responses are pretty much graded pass/pass. You can get away with skimming the readings, since whats more important is taking detailed notes in class. Take this class if you are interested in cognitive science, but be wary of its weaknesses.
save your soul and GPA and do NOT take this class.
Absolutely.

YES!

Background: a prospective CS major first-year who are interested in artificial intelligence. I've learned AP psychology.

If you have known concepts in intro to psych and are fascinated by how our mind works, I'd recommend taking this course with Brian Scholl.

Take this because the material is interesting but if you don't like corny jokes and getting of class late every single day (this is not an exaggeration. at. all.) you may become increasingly frustrated with Professor Scholl and the class in general. The workload is very simple and straightforward. Readings and Responses, a midterm, a final, and a paper.
I think it's a really interesting class that introduces to you well the variety of approaches you may be thinking of taking when pursuing cognitive science. It's basically like a Ted Talk every day.

You learn a lot about yourself (and human minds in general)! The material is very interesting, the grad students are very receptive to questions, and Professor Scholl is a clear and entertaining lecturer who'll make it worth your time.

If you are interested in the major take this class (mostly because you have too). Otherwise I don't see the point, I think some of the intro psychology classes are more interesting. Also be warned that Scholl has a bit of an ego and he often starts class late then goes overtime.

Yes, I would recommend this course. I think it is a good introduction to an emerging field. You also learn a lot about humans, and this information is relevant to us all. Even for those who are not considering CogSci as a major, I think this course is worthwhile.
Yes, the class was extremely interesting and engaging.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. It is great not only for people specifically interested in cogsci, but for anyone curious about why humans are the way we are. It explores many daily occurrences that we are all familiar with, but don't know how or why they happen and don't really take the time to think about. As Professor Scholl says, this courses teaches students to "marvel at the commonplace", which I think most students would find intriguing.
I wouldn't if a student didn't have to. I think there are other, more linear courses out there.

If you're looking for an easy, interesting class, this is the class for you. The class has VERY little workload (like a ridiculously low amount), but it actually is pertinent to many real-world topics and is incredibly entertaining. I think Scholl is also a great professor, super engaging.
ABSOLUTELY

If you're looking for a SO requirement that you actually may learn a thing or two from, then I'd recommend this course. If you're thinking about the cog sci major, it's worth taking this class to get a sense of the field as a whole.
Yes, it is a very interesting course and has a minimal workload.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is a lot of work at times, but the amount of crazy interesting things you learn in that class is incredible. I would take it again.

I would definitely recommend this class to first years interested the social sciences, as it introduces many fields to the student. An array of subjects like psych, neuroscience, compsci, and linguistics are all covered by the lectures, so it is a great way to test the waters and see what may interest you. 
Some lectures include 3D glasses, visual illusions, and games, so though the material can be difficult to grasp at times, the content is always fun. I went from econ115 to cogsci every Monday and Wednesday, and this lecture never failed to wake me up and excite me. 
The workload is also very manageable. Weekly readings and short responses to the readings can be expected, followed by a midterm, paper, and final. That's it for grades! Compared to other classes, this workload isn't didn't stress me out nearly as much as other classes.

Even if you don't pursue cognitive science (this class is the prereq to the major), I still recommend taking this class. I had a lot of interested in the different fields that cognitive science draws together, so for me, it was fascinating to see them work in tandem to figure out how the mind works. I feel like I know so much more about the mind and society as a whole; this is information I can't imagine living without because it is simply so interesting.
I would just because Scholl is a great lecturer and the material is fascinating. It's just really fun to learn a little bit about a lot of aspects of Cognitive Science.
I would recommend this class to other students as it is fascinating but they should take it Credit D Fail as it is hard to get an A in this class.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this class to another student if you're even slightly entertaining the idea of majoring in cogsci. It's a great survey course to expose you to a bunch of cogsci's different subfields. I had a friend who audited the class because he couldn't fit it in his schedule, and he gained a lot from the lectures as well.

Yes, but I recommend taking it Credit-D. I thought I had done well on the first exam, but I ended up failing it. Concepts can be trickier than they seem. The twice-a-week reading responses are also very annoying. With that said, I learned a lot of really cool new material in this class. Some demonstrations really blew my mind. I also really liked the guest lecturers. I am happy I took this for my Psych requirements over Human Brain!

I would recommend this course to a student who wants to explore different fields. This course covers topics that are included in psychology, neuroscience, and philosophy. So taking this course would help the student in choosing their path or major for the future.
Yes. Very insightful, learned a lot.
I would. It is very interesting and not too much work to be enjoyable.
If you are looking for a chill class in terms of weekly work, but you don't have to know as much until the midterm and final.
Take it even if you're a senior! You will find that the course changes the way you understand the world.

I would not recommend this course to another student. Professor Scholl can focus too much on being funny, rather than presenting the material in a clear, coherent manner. There are a lot of individual experiments that are showcased, yet not much information on basic definitions and concepts to better explain the experiments.
I would recommend this course strongly. Interesting material, great lecturer, strong option for an intro sequence to the brain.

this is my second time taking this--i dropped it last year after bombing the midterm. i only took it because i needed it as a core for psyc. that being said, it wasn't awful even the second time around. scholl knows his stuff, and while it can sometimes be difficult to know whether he's just rambling or saying material you'll eventually be tested on, i feel like i learned a lot about the mind--and also that i still have so much left to learn. learn turing machines. you'll hate them but just suck it up and learn them.

I would recommend this class to someone looking for an intro to social sciences in general. It's generally enjoyable and interesting, is taught well, and the challenge felt fair (not too easy, but not stressfully difficult).

CogSci is a course that really is what you make of it. The weekly workload is fairly small (the reading responses honestly aren't that bad) which means that some students lower their guard a bit too much--getting blindsided during the exams. If you actually pay attention in lecture and do the responses, the course is pretty easy. Also Professor Scholl is a great lecturer, who always finds a way to bring fun into the material.

This class was everything that I wanted from an introductory course--it was fun, not too much work, interactive, fascinating, and very interesting. I never once fell asleep in lecture (Scholl is a very animated lecturer who always keeps you on your toes with his (sometimes distasteful but hilarious regardless) jokes), which is more than I can say for most classes. One of my favorite things about this class is that everything we learn can be directly applied and observed in real life; everything we learn changes a fraction of my perception of the world. "A common man marvels at uncommon things. A wise man marvels at common things" was a quote we were shown in the very first lecture. This class definitely taught me how to marvel at common things and to subsequently see the beauty and complexity of all the little things around me.

I would definitely recommend because the class covers topics that wouldn't be covered in any other class such as the innateness of language. Understanding how the mind works only improves our understanding of ourselves, which can be used to create positive change in the real world.
yes
Definitely, this was my favorite course!

I definitely would --not only to intended Cognitive Science majors but to all! This is a course that teaches us about how our minds work. It helps us to understand ourselves better and find ways to approach our world better.

Definitely! I think it is an excellent bridge of disciplines, which very well represents the liberal arts mentality of Yale students. It gives knowledge into something which we use every day and which is of great -maybe only?- relevance in university: the mind.

I would recommend it to someone who has philosophical thoughts but doesnt like the idea of studying philosophy
The class strikes an excellent balance between exploring both head in the clouds kind of subject matter as well as down to earth and everyday phenomena
Take this class! It is so important to know at least a little bit about how we think and how others think. Prof Scholl is hilarious and a joy.
YES YES YES
I would recommend this course to any student interested in a broad, entertaining introduction to cognitive science.

I don't feel like this course will give you an entirely new perspective on the mind or how we perceive the world, but it will definitley introduce you to a great amount of theories and aspects on how to examine the way we think. The course work is easily managed and the lectures are rarely boring. Would recommend.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It opens your mind not just to a new subject area, but also to a new perspective on the human mind and human life.
Yes because I think he was a great professor to listen to and I learned a lot.
yes
Yes, this course was very interesting, not too much work, and had clear real life implications.
Absolutely. It is very interesting and has a ton of real world application.
Definitely take if at all interested in any cognitive science field.

I believe that this class is very interesting and could be taken by anyone, even if it has no relevance to their major. You learn many new things about a completely new field of research that has great potential for future discoveries.
I would highly recommend this course to another student. The subject material is fascinating and Professor Scholl is a funny, knowledgeable, and incredible lecturer.

Overall, I would recommend this course to another student. Cognitive science is a fascinating field, and this course provides a solid introduction to it. Because cognitive science is such a broad field, this intro course could only skim the surface of it; expect to gain a breadth of information but not much depth. I would recommend this course to a student interested in learning what cognitive science is about.
Yes, you can get a taste of what cognitive science is about

Yes absolutely. I've been recommending this class to all my friends since day one. Professor Scholl's lectures are like watching a TED talk twice a week and any random one can completely change your perspective on how you think about any given topic. Definitely one of the few "must-take" courses at Yale, CogSci major or not.
Yes, I learned so many interesting things
I would tell them this was my favorite class and the reason I am choosing to major in Cognitive Science!

I would highly recommend this student who is genuinely interested in the subject. If not, the course may seem to be tedious and all too detailed. For those intrigued by the course material, it will prove to be one of the most interesting and enlightening courses you can take.
Yes! If you're willing to go to lectures and really engage with the material -- definitely take this class.

I would recommend this course to a first-year who is still going to laugh at Professor Scholl's jokes, probably has a lot of friends in the class to share study materials, and hasn't taken Psych 110 (it overlaps so much that Cog Sci is made a bit dull). Personally, I would recommend taking the intro classes in all the things Cog Sci touches on: Linguistic, Stat, Psych, CPSC, Phil, but since that takes a lot of time, Cog Sci is a decent introduction to those areas.

Absolutely! If you have any interest in cognitive science, whether as a major or not, take this course (especially with Brian). Low stress, fun lecture, and a springboard to interesting future studies. Great course for your first semester.

I would recommend Cognitive Science to students who are interested in psychology's intersection with many other disciplines, with the caveat that there is more breadth involved in the course than depth, and not as much structure.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student. It is an interesting topic to learn about and not an overwhelming amount of work if you're not sure that cognitive science is the route for you.

I would not recommend this course to students who are not interested in majoring in Cognitive Science. The course is difficult, and it is not as interesting or as well-run as Intro Psych. If you are interested in computer science and artificial intelligence, the course might be somewhat more interesting.

The class structure isn't formatted in a way that is easily/universally understood, as an intro class should be. It's for a very specific kind of learner. The grading is also really strange; students in the dark about their performance throughout the semester. However, the class gives you a broad introduction to a lot of topics, because that's what an intro class is supposed to be like, and the lectures are easy to follow.

the professor says some controversial things. i like him a lot better as a teacher and a professor of cognitive science than as a person. the material is really interesting and his lectures are well thought out and well delivered. whether or not your TA is good or not highly influences how this class will go for you. overall a good class with less than average workload and a heavy curve, good material. go to class everyday, would recommend
Yes, absolutely take it!

Decent course. About 20 minutes (or less) of important stuff in each lecture, pretty much. If you keep up with the notes and know what is important and what isn't, you'll do well. The important stuff is what Scholl talks about a lot. Some people like Scholl, some people don't. I found him kind of annoying. It's a pretty chill SO credit though, if you need one. Not like an incredible class filled with incredible learning tho,

The course is structured fairly well, with the lectures usually posted before class begins. The lectures are clear and understandable. It would be great if the lectures posted online contained all the graphic images and content that is seen in class. It's hard to catch up on a lecture if you miss a class and have to rely on these vague PDFs. The course has 2 midterms, and 1 paper. The grade is made up of those and participation from the reading responses you submit every Monday and Wednesday based on the reading that is assigned. The readings are fairly helpful and responses are straightforward to do. The midterm material is quite random, and based on random things focused on in class. If you're a senior, make sure you don't have interviews or have to be out of town on any day this lecture is offered. Otherwise, you will fail the midterm. Take notes on everything, because you will never really know what will be on the exam. Concepts are key to know, but its hard to know from the lectures the definite answer to some questions. It may be best to take this class credit D.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in cognitive science or any of its subdisciplines. The class moves really quickly from one subject to the next, but since Professor Scholl introduces you to so many topics, at least a few of them are bound to interest you. The lectures are engaging and the workload is not strenuous.
Of course, a lot of valuable things are to be learned from this course.
Yes, absolutely. Professor Scholl is an incredible lecturer, and the material is fascinating and very applicable to every day life, even if you are not interested in pursuing cognitive science.

I would recommend this to another student that was willing to do their best to understand abstract concepts and not get discouraged when the material did not necessarily come easily. The coconuts were very intriguing and they were fun to learn about however it took someones a lot of studying in order to truly understand the concepts.
If you are interested in taking other cognitive science courses, it is a prerequisite, but other than that, I found it to be a bit more stressful than it would be worth.
Yes. Not overwhelming but also interesting

If you're looking for a fun, interesting, low-stress course, I'd recommend this class. Professor Scholl does a great job, and even though you don't walk away feeling like an expert in cognitive science, you do learn a lot about a lot of different, useful things. It's not too much work, though you do actually have to study for the midterm and final and put some effort into the final paper, and it's actually fun to go to each class and learn about something interesting.
yes
I definitely would recommend this course. I think it is engaging, and has something for all types of students.

Yes, I would recommend the class to anyone who wants an to balance out their workload with light lectures. A solid introductory course and a good idea if you don't actually know what you want to study and would like to be exposed to all different areas of the cognitive science field.
No. Brian Scholl is a good lecture but does not seem to care for individual students at all.
Yes absolutely, if you are interested in the study of the mind.

I think you learn a lot in this class, but I think the grading is absurdly inconsistent, and anyone who wants to take this class should know that students in previous semesters have made similar complaints.
Yes - but with the warning that the course is extremely broad and feels very surface level. It feels a lot more like memorization of a ~ a lot ~ of very different things.
Yes I would.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It was my favorite for the semester. And before taking it I had no background in the field and never considered a future in it, but after taking the intro course I may even major in it. After every class I would call family and text friends the mind blowing things we covered.
Its a pretty light workload but tests are easy to mess up on.
Yes
Yes, especially if the student wants to be aware of other's action even if her/his major is not related to the course.
I definitely would.

I would recommend this class to another student because I believe the information we learned is important and intriguing. It is applicable to the real world, and can open some people's eyes to a field of study they are not usually exposed to.

Brian's lecture is a force of nature. Fitting that a cog sci professor would be able in a less-than-purely-metaphorical way to reach into the minds of hundreds of students and materialize the exact crystalline structure of a certain difficult concept. Brian's lab is called Perception; his lecture should be called Inception: you will leave lecture with an understanding and conviction that tends to come only when you yourself have made the groundbreaking discovery after years of toil. Don't ever let anyone say, "I can't explain this to you, it's too complicated" - I had a better conceptual understanding of quantum mechanics (relevant for fMRI imaging) after Brian's 2-minute overview than after my first two QM lectures last semester.

Ok, back to earth with this rec. I am a junior computer science major who took the class for an SO credit. Tough grading visa-vie peers who are more cog-sci focused (I worked reasonably hard and am around a B). Would recommend due to very profound material that is hilariously well explicated by Brian.
I would absolutly recommend this course. It was filled with interesting information that, as a person that is not particularly interested in science, still garnered my attention and awe.
Yes, it is a good introduction but very surface-level.

This course is extremely interesting. I learned so much about the brain and how it works. 

Brian Scholl is funny and engaging (although his jokes to start to wear) and teaches in an easy-to-understand way. 

Workload isn't bad. There are reading responses due before every class but they are basically graded for completion and only have to be a paragraph long. The exams aren't too difficult...it's just hard to know what's going to be on them.
Anyone who is unsure of what field of science they want to go into, or just wants to learn more about the way humans think should definitely take this course.

Great class. Not too much work, every class you have one short reading response (rarely two), two midterms overall, and one paper. Overall, this is one of the classes I loved going to everyday and I actually looked forward to it. The topic matter is interesting and Brian is an amazing lecturer, super interesting guy, and adds comedy to his lectures making them very enjoyable.

If you've already taken other psychology/neuroscience/linguistics courses, cogsci will definitely be easier for you (but its a requirement for the cogsci major, so you still have to take it even if you've taken more advanced courses in cogsci). If you're an upperclassman looking for an Social Science credit, you could definitely find other classes that would be more interesting. But I would recommend intro cogsci to first semester freshmen. 

Beware, the exams are harder than expected because the multiple choice questions are quite specific. Other than studying for exams, this course doesnt require much work, but lectures are still engaging. You definitely need to go to class bc lecture slides are very minimal and wont be useful unless you go to class

I would recommend this course to another student. I found the material very interesting and thought provoking and I think if they are at all interested in learning cool, rather random things about the way our cognitive system functions, they would enjoy the course.

I would recommend this course to anyone looking for a survey of cognitive science, and to any STEM majors looking for a social science credit. It's not too intellectually challenging, and I frequently lost interest in the lectures because they were a bit slow and tedious. Just be prepared to write 40 reading responses throughout the semester.
Yes, especially for students with no prior interaction with the domain of cognitive science. A really good teaser!
Yes, it was interesting and I learned a lot. I feel like people should be introduced to this new science.
